Fields.DialogueText: Look at those SBD-2s swoop, Captain! Damn, sometimes I wish I were an aircraft! It looks like so much fun!
I didn't know you had aspirations towards flight, Enterprise.
I know how to operate every gun on this ship, Captain. I know how to run the communications devices, fix the engines, fix the aircraft... I've worked every role on this ship at one time or another.
Except pilot. I'd love to be able to fly.
I've never told anyone that before.
Your connection to the ship prevents you?
I can only go a very short distance, not even far enough to take off in a SBD-2. Or else I'd be up there in an instant!
Have you ever flown, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: A few times. It's exhilarating being up so high.
Once or twice. It's not as fun as you would think.
No, I'm as ground bound as you are, fortunately.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, I know it would be!
You clearly don't appreciate it, Captain. There are so many things you take for granted!
Not so fortunate. If you flew, I could live vicariously through your experiences.
I'd like my Belle's head out of the clouds by the time we reach Brazil.
Captain, I'm admiring the skill of my pilots, not daydreaming. Besides, I think this drill will turn into something far more exciting. My RDF just picked up a ship moving in our direction.
A Morgana?
Of course. Look, behind us! There's a plane on the horizon.
That's definitely not a Neutrality Fleet aircraft. It looks like we're dealing with a Morgana aircraft carrier.
No Morgana could outclass me!
@BATTLE
I've never seen you turn up your nose at my chef's cooking before.
Hah, your chef is as talented as always, Captain! I'm just looking forward to a taste of home in Brazil...
A taste of home? You're one of the most American Belles I've met.
How many American Belles have you met, hmm? Brazil is like a second home to me. It's where my first captain sailed me on my shake-up cruise. Those coasts taught me a lot.
Ah, I understand. You call many places home.
It's true! I do have a special place in my heart for Brazil, though... and feijoada.
It's a sort of stew, a Portuguese dish. I first got a sense of it back during that first cruise... Feijoada and cachaça, sugarcane liquor... you'll never taste anything better, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'll make sure some of both are brought on board for you.
You're thinking about food at a time like this? We're at war.
I know what it is. I just didn't think it would be your sort of dish.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain! You're a cool cat.
And feijoada keeps my engines running, Captain! Well... figuratively, at least!
What, ‘cause I'm American? It's good food, Captain!
Well, you'll have to set aside thoughts of port and stew for the moment at least. If I'm not mistaken, those are Morganas on the horizon.
@BATTLE
Fine weather today, Captain!
Fine now, but it looks like a storm is rolling in on the horizon.
I love the weather in South America. It's beautiful in all permutations.
We might just have a stormy fight today, Captain! There's a Morgana on the horizon, under the cover of that storm.
You're right. Look at those aircraft in the clouds!
That's an aircraft carrier behind them - but not Sin! We lost her after the last fight. Our pilots will have to be quick!
@BATTLE
What was that?! One of their pilots must have lost control...
Enterprise, get down! It looks like it's going to-
*BOOM*
Augh. That... that hit us hard, Captain. What was that?! Airplanes don't explode like that! Or at least, they shouldn't!
How badly are you damaged, Enterprise?
I can still fight, Captain.
Honestly?
... I'll float, but we're in no shape to go chasing after that Morgana now, and we're a sitting target.
If there are any more of them lurking around, she could draw them to us.
We can kill the power and communications and lose them in the storm.
It will put our fighter squadron at risk. They might not able to make it back without communications.
... You're right, Captain. But it's a risk we have to take.

Fields.MenuText: It's the right decision.
It's the only course of action we can take right now.
... Unfortunately, you're right.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you think so. ... It's hard to admit it, but I'm not sure we could repel another attack, especially one like that.
Unfortunately. Our pilots are capable. They'll be all right. I have confidence in them.
It's the best way to keep the whole ship safe. I'm sorry, Captain.
I believe in our squadrons.
I know they believe in you, too.
Enterprise... watching the skies won't help. The planes that haven't returned are lost, in all likelihood.
The communications officers haven't been able to restore contact with them, and it's far beyond when they should have returned.
... That storm was likely one of the most violent they had ever flown in.
We had no way of knowing how bad it would be.
... I know. Captain, the damage report is ready, if you want to read it...
Hmm. We'll have to make port to pick up supplies for the repairs, but we were planning to do that in Rio de Janeiro anyway.
I've never seen a plane used like that before in aerial combat. It was used like a shell, but with far more direction... It's a tactic that we could never utilize.
I can't comprehend how they can. Who pilots Morgana fighters, anyway? Can they manifest themselves in aircraft?
Depends on the Morgana, I think. The fleet has had a hell of time gathering information on Morganas, and they're not always forthcoming with that information anyway...
Captain, we've got another problem. My RDF just picked up unidentified ships heading towards us quickly. We should prepare for a fight!
@BATTLE
Captain, I've been helping the crew investigate the remnants of the plane that crashed into my deck...
What have they found? Anything interesting?
The plane was of German make. Some of the fuselage still had the markings of a Luftwaffe fighter.
The Morganas take pieces from the ships they capture...
They must do the same for airplanes. It would make sense, I suppose, I just hadn't thought about it before.
And the pilot?
We couldn't recover much of the body, but it was human. Undoubtedly.
A brainwashed captive, more than likely.
Perhaps. I can't imagine anyone willingly signing up with the Morganas, but some people are cowards. They would rather follow strength than show courage.

Fields.MenuText: I doubt anyone would work for a Morgana willingly.
You're right. And there are plenty of cowards in the world.
Choosing the side most likely to win isn't cowardice, it's good sense.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't want to believe anyone would, either, Captain. Traitors are the worst kind of people.
I wouldn't say plenty, but I know there are some. Traitors of the worst kind.
Captain! Abandoning your fellows for the sake of your own life is the definition of cowardice!
We should pass along our findings to the fleet. I can ask the other Belles - Captain! We were supposed to rendezvous with Hyūga, were we not?
Yes, we should be within TBS distance with her soon...
I think there's a Morgana group up ahead that's hunting her as well. We may be damaged, but we can lend her a few guns of support at least!
@BATTLE
I'm glad to be away from that rendezvous. Did you learn anything useful from Hyūga's captain?
What's put such a sour look on your face? Hyūga isn't a Belle, is she?
... No. But that doesn't mean she can't communicate her real feelings of disdain.
What are you talking about?
She's old. Old for a ship, at least, and traditional. She'd prefer aircraft carriers stay where they belong... in the back lines, not gallivanting off to South America to chase Morganas.
She thinks it's my own reckless behavior that got me damaged and my pilots killed. I could feel her sneering at me.
That's a strong opinion for a non-Belle ship.
Other ships can have strong opinions without being Belles, Captain. They're not stupid. And I like most of them. But that Hyūga... she just wanted to put me in my place.

Fields.MenuText: An old relic like that is the one who has no place fighting Morganas.
I don't think I'd want to get involved in a conflict of personality between a battleship and an aircraft carrier.
Well... she has a point. Sometimes you are a bit reckless.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly! Though... the fleet needs every ship it can get.
Hah, that's probably wise, Cap. It's no matter! It's unlikely we'll run into her again anytime soon.
And she's a lumbering old elephant from another age! I would take reckless over outdated any day.
Hah, well, I passed on our findings from the Morgana aircraft to Hyūga's captain. I was told that other ships have been suffering the same sort of attacks.
We'll have to adjust our strategies to avoid being hit like that again.
It will be hard when we're missing a whole squadron of fighters, Captain.
Ah, well, I did get another piece of good news.
We're going to make port in Natal in Rio Grande do Norte, and there pick up a few replacement planes and pilots from the Brazilian Expeditionary Force.
That's... good. That's good, Captain.
Hyūga's captain also gave me word of a Morgana battleship that has been raiding the coastal towns, slipping past the watch of the local and American naval forces in the area.
Are you up for a bit of hunting?
Always, Captain.
@BATTLE
Good. We're about to get some practice in...
Enterprise... How are you feeling? You've been sitting out here for a while.
I was just looking out at the city, Cap. Isn't it gorgeous? Especially at this time of day...
It is. Have you been here before?
No, Captain. On my shakeup cruise, we went to Rio de Janeiro, not Rio Grande do Norte. That was lovely, too. It was my first adventure...
You made the right decision, you know. You shouldn't let whatever Hyūga thought of you get to you. We did what had to be done.
I mourn the pilots we lost too, but what you suggested saved the rest of the crew.
... I know, Cap. Thank you. It feels good to hear it from your mouth. If I had a second chance to do things differently, I know I would make the same decision.
I just wanted to check up on you. It's what you would do for me if I had made the call, isn't it?
Yes, of course. ... Thank you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'm proud of you, Enterprise. You've grown into a much more confident Belle.
I'm glad to have you by my side, Enterprise.
Thank you for choosing me as your captain, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Thank you. I'm proud of you, too, Captain. I really am.
... And I'm glad to have you as my captain.
It was the best reckless decision I've made in my life.
Also, I had a few officers pick you up something in the city...
What is it? Ah! Feijoada! It is, isn't it? Thank you, Captain! You remembered!
Of course I did.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Grr... this better not get cold!
Captain! Have you met any of our new pilots yet? Their first lieutenant is quite the character.
I met him in passing, but I've been busy talking to the fleet brass in Natal. What's your impression of him? Luiz, isn't that his name?
That's him! I like him already! He has the sort of attitude I like in my pilots.
Reckless?
No, Captain. Quick-witted and ready to rise to a challenge. I was impressed at his enthusiasm to leave home so quickly, given what's being asked of him.
I'm glad he feels ready for the challenge. Do you think the rest of the pilots are ready as well?
He certainly thinks they are. I haven't seen them fly yet, so I can't judge. But he's certainly eager to take on the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: I'll take his enthusiasm as a good sign.
That sort of enthusiasm can be dangerous.
I hope he's not some sort of glory hound.

Fields.DialogueText: I will, too. I have a hunch he'll prove to be an asset.
I agree, but a few battles will likely temper it.
I doubt that Cap. He's reportedly one of the best Brazil has to offer.
I hope he and the other Brazilian pilots will settle in quickly. The war is moving too fast to give anyone much time to adjust.
It appears they may have even less time than we expected. Captain, there's a Morgana on my RDF. She's heading in towards the port. And she brought friends.
Not the smartest Morgana, it seems, attacking the combined power of the United States and Brazilian navies. We should teach her a lesson.
Morganas are so hard to school, aren't they?
@BATTLE
Ha! That's a lesson I don't think she'll forget!
Our new pilots performed well.
They did! Lieutenant Luiz did a remarkable job. He's ace material.
Enterprise! Tell me, am I delusional, or are there fewer cats than usual on board?
You're not delusional, Captain. I gave one of Lu's litter to Hyūga. I'm surprised it took you this long to notice!
I thought you didn't like Hyūga. She certainly didn't seem to have any respect for you.
It's bad luck to set to sea without a cat, Captain. I figure, in these times, with the Morgana fleet getting stronger every day... even Hyūga needs some luck.
Especially with that Morgana aircraft carrier's new destructive tactics... an exploding plane could do much worse to the boards of an old, flammable Japanese ship like Hyūga.

Fields.MenuText: That's very generous of you, Enterprise.
I'll be glad to have one fewer cat to trip over.
Aren't you worried she'll take poor care of the cat?

Fields.DialogueText: It's just common courtesy, Cap! I may not like her, but we're all together in this fight.
Don't say that, you know you like them!
Oh, no, I know she won't. Besides, she still sleeps, and no smart crew will abuse a cat. Cats are useful.
Besides luck, it will help her cut down on her rat population... and you know, on old ships like that, it's easier for the rats to hide up in crevices.
Nobody taught you to respect your elders, did they?
I give respect to those who earn it, not snide battleships who wouldn't know a floatplane from a fighter plane.
But speaking of vermin, I think we've got another Morgana trying to sneak up behind us, Captain! It will be good to get into a proper fight.
@BATTLE
Captain! I really have been impressed by the pilots from the Brazilian Expeditionary Force. They've performed well, despite being thrust into the thick of things.
That's not what Lieutenant Luiz tells me. He pulled me aside this morning to ask why you had taken his pilots to task like you did.
You've got to keep pilots on their toes. Especially since they're new to our ship - and are used to being more independent, I imagine.

Fields.MenuText: I do remember you treating the crew this way the first time we set out.
Still, it wouldn't hurt to throw them some scraps of praise now and then.
You shouldn't be so harsh. You'll foster dissent, not loyalty.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly! They know I'm just pushing them to be better, and they love me for it. No harm done!
I suppose you're probably right... but there's no harm in pushing them!
What, Captain? I'm giving them a bit of grief, not spitting on their graves. Do you think I can't handle a few pilots properly?
Still, maybe I should brush up on my Portuguese. Things can get lost in translation. I should talk to Lieutenant Luiz... I wouldn't want him thinking I didn't like him or his pilots.
You're awfully worried about what he thinks, aren't you?
... What? Not especially... If you're suggesting that I...
Enterprise?
My RDF is picking up Morganas a short distance from us, Captain, off the coast. We should pursue them!
... Of course. We'll speak later.
@BATTLE
Have you and Lieutenant Luiz settled your differences? I saw you playing cards with him in the wardroom earlier today.
I think we have, Captain. I've explained to him my harsh remarks are meant to encourage, not to insult the hard work of his pilots.
He's been helping me brush up on my Portuguese. I was even rustier than I thought!
Good. It's never good to have a rift in a crew.
I wouldn't call it a rift, Captain, just a misunderstanding. I should have explained a thing or two about myself before jumping into ordering his men around.
After all, he's never been on a ship with a Belle before.
Hah, that's right. You don't look like your standard officer.
What do you mean by that, Captain?! I think I'm a perfectly military Belle!

Fields.MenuText: The clothes you wear aren't military issue.
You're not very... intimidating.
Never mind, I shouldn't have said anything.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm here to fight, not to look pretty.
I'm 19,800 tons of steel, Cap! I'd say that's intimidating!
You can't slip out of an answer that easily, Captain!
It just takes everyone some time to get used to the idea of Belles. You know that.
Of course, Captain. But this is wartime! Everyone must be ready for the ground to move under them, or they won't survive. They've got to adjust.
Speaking of adjustment, I think our course is due for one. A Morgana we've been told to hunt has been spotted north of here.
Perhaps another fight will convince Lieutenant Luiz of my military qualities!
I think he is quite convinced after our last few battles, Enterprise.
@BATTLE
Hypnotized by the aircraft again?
Oh! Captain! I didn't hear you.
You looked absorbed. The Brazilians seem to pilot their crafts very well.
Ah, that's not what I was looking at, though they definitely do. Look beyond our aircraft. See those shapes above the water?
The birds?
Gaviotas! Also called frigate birds, or man o' war birds. They're similar to albatrosses.
Do people constantly misrepresent them as being harbingers of bad luck, when the Rime of the Ancient Mariner clearly says otherwise?
No, no. They're a little like American bald eagles, in a way. They symbolize freedom in some places, and the end of a journey in others.
One of my crew whittled me a little carving of one, toward the end of my first cruise... He was the one who gave me the idea to start carving my airplanes.
Does every trinket on your belt tell a story?
Hah, well, not stories exactly. Most of them are pretty uninteresting, like that one. But it's like... a journal of where I'm from, and where I've been.
Tokens of your predecessors... your aircraft... your navy crest...
This is a Virginia rose, for my home... this is a piece of the metal that was forged into my torpedo blister...
That reminds me. I... I'd like to add something that represents you, at some point. You're another important thing in my travels.

Fields.MenuText: I would be honored, Enterprise. I think I can find something fitting.
I don't know what could represent me to you.
I'm a thing, am I?

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, thank you, Captain! Take your time, there's no rush.
It's hard to sum up anything in just an object... but it's more a memento than anything else. It doesn't have to have obvious meaning.
You know what I mean!
What am I to you, Enterprise?
... That's a strange question. You're my captain! The one I chose, out of everyone, to be my partner.
... Well, I'll consider what could represent me. In the meantime...
In the meantime, Morganas are trying to get by us to the coast!
@BATTLE
What's that you have, Enterprise?
These? Confidential correspondence, of course.
Confidential correspondence for whom?
Me, of course! Look, here's my name on the envelope. To Miss USS Enterprise, USS Enterprise...
I didn't realize Belles were in the navy postage system. You don't need letters to talk to other Belles at a distance, do you?
No, but I do have human friends. Civilians.
So who's the letter from?
That's confidential, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: It must be important, to be kept a secret even from your captain.
Very well. I'll let you have your secrets.
Don't play games with me, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: It's nothing to worry about, Captain. Just a bit of business.
Thank you, Captain!
I'm not playing games, but these letters aren't for your eyes.
You can be an obstinate Belle, did you know that?
Sticking to your guns is important. If these letters were of any importance, I would show you. They're just not intended for you.
Very well. We've got some new orders. We're to lend aid to the Alagoas. Her captain is having trouble guarding the coast. Are you ready for another hunt?
Of course, Captain.
@BATTLE
Have you read the missive from Captain Oliveira yet?
Of course! I saw it as soon as it came in.
She sounded panicked. She may be in over her head, but we'll deal with her Morgana problem!

Fields.MenuText: Of course! We should be able to ease some of her burden.
The fleet should be mindful not to let their ships get overtaxed.
Perhaps she isn't fit for duty fighting Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: We will, I have no doubt of that! A Belle can turn any battle, especially a Belle like me.
We're spread thin, Captain, but a ship with a Belle can do a great deal more than a regular ship. We'll help the Alagoas and her crew!
Is anyone, truly? We're all doing the best we can - you, me, and Captain Oliviera and her crew.
Do you know Captain Oliviera? You seem familiar with her.
We met back on my shakeup cruise. She's not the cleverest commander, but she's a steadfast one. She's been with her ship for some time, and the old Alagoas is very devoted to her.
She's been dealing with the same Morgana aircraft carrier we fought. Delusion.
A formidable foe, but we've fought her off before! We should let Captain Oliviera know we'll be with her shortly.
Perhaps not so soon as we might want. What's that, there, on the horizon?
A Morgana battleship! Lieutenant Luiz owes me. I bet him that his pilots would see combat before we reached the Alagoas!
@BATTLE
Captain! There's the Alagoas! It looks like Delusion has her under fire!
That doesn't look good for Captain Oliviera. All hands to stations!
Captain, look at the path of those fighter planes! I think they're going to crash into-
Damn! The same tactic Delusion used on us.
The Alagoas can't withstand that! She's... she's going to sink, Captain.
We've got to fight off Delusion.
You're right. If we finish this quickly, we may be able to save Alagoas's crew! Time is of the essence, Captain!
@BATTLE
Look at that! She's just a bully. She can't stand up to a Belle and her captain!
Well done. But the Alagoas...
We've got to hurry and save her crew. She's sinking quickly.

Fields.MenuText: We'll make one pass and be off. We don't know whether this area is safe.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing doing, Captain. We're in this until everyone's aboard me or at the bottom of the sea.

Fields.MenuText: Until everyone that can be saved is.

Fields.DialogueText: Nobody gets left behind, Captain. We'll show those Morganas how to treat your own right.

Fields.MenuText: Think you can make it?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll never forgive myself if I don't try, Captain.
Has Captain Oliviera been found yet, Captain? I've been helping the nurses in sickbay deal with the rescued crew.
She's not in any of the lifeboats we've recovered so far. It's likely she went down with Alagoas.
... That makes sense. From what I remember of her, she would feel it was her duty.
Enterprise?
I wish we had been able to save her.

Fields.MenuText: We saved most of the Alagoas's crew, Enterprise.
We did our best.
We can't always win, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true. That's important. I just don't like losing anyone.
Our best isn't always enough, Captain.
Yes we can, Captain. We can! We just need to try harder.
Enterprise... what was that quote they sent you off on your first cruise with? The one from Othello?
“May she also say with just pride - I have done the State some service.”
Some service, Enterprise. You don't have to succeed at all you do. You just have to do it.
... You're right, Captain.
There's ships on my RDF, Captain! They're definitely not civvies. There are still lifeboats in the water! We've got to protect them, Captain.
Of course.
@BATTLE
Enterprise! What was all that shouting about? Half the crew could hear you and Lieutenant Luiz!
We had an argument.
Obviously. What was it about? I was under the impression he was fond of you.
I said that I thought that the fleet should send non-Brazilian ships here to aid in the defense of the coast. Preferably ships that are newer, with crews who have more experience in war.
And he took offense?
He said the Brazilian Navy is perfectly capable of doing their part for the fleet and defending their own country. I think I really offended him, Captain.
I don't understand why. Better ships and crews mean more protection for the coast.

Fields.MenuText: That's a fact. He shouldn't have taken offense to it.
Lieutenant Luiz and his pilots certainly have proven themselves capable.
Insulting people's countries generally doesn't make friends.

Fields.DialogueText: That's what I thought, but I clearly upset him. I didn't mean to!
You're right, they have. I didn't mean to imply that Brazilian forces are incompetent; only that they're smaller and lack the resources of the combined fleet.
... You're right, Captain. I guess I might have insulted Brazil without realizing it.
... I suppose if someone insinuated I was incapable of protecting America, I would be upset too. I should apologize to him.
You probably should, but wait until he's cooled off first.
He should have an opportunity to blow off steam. My RDF just picked up a Morgana!
@BATTLE
Captain...
What is it, Enterprise? Have you been fighting with Lieutenant Luiz again?
No. Do you remember the plane that sunk the Alagoas? One of the search parties we sent out looking for survivors picked up a few fragments of the plane's fuselage, and...
It looks like it comes from an SBD-2.
... Like the planes we lost.
Exactly. Do you think that Delusion captured our planes in that storm and took our pilots prisoner? It might have been one of our own who sunk the Alagoas.
That's a disturbing thought.

Fields.MenuText: It may be true, but I doubt any of our pilots would have done it willingly.
It's more likely Delusion fished the already wrecked planes out of the sea and repaired them.
There's no way to tell.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. The Morganas are strange though... I've heard reports of their abilities.
You're right. That does sound more likely. Not that I'm happy our men are dead, but I hate the thought of them destroying their own.
You're right. I shouldn't dwell on it.
There's nothing that can be done, either way. The only thing we can do is fight off the Morganas and try our best to keep our crew safe.
That's not always possible, Enterprise. It is their job - and ours - to fight.
I know that! I'm not naive when it comes to fighting, Captain. But losing crewmen will never stop being painful, even if it has happened dozens of times over.
... Damn it, I'm sensing Morganas. I'm... We're not losing anyone else.
@BATTLE
Who left flowers in the wardroom? I caught a glimpse of them when I walked past.
What? Oh, Lieutenant Luiz, I think. He must have picked them up in Natal when we dropped off the Alagoas's crew.
I think he's trying to cheer me up.

Fields.MenuText: That's sweet of him.
What odd behavior.
No one ever gets me flowers...

Fields.DialogueText: It is. It certainly made me smile! Even if it's odd.
I know, isn't it? I guess he realized I was, well... sad.
Ha! You do know how to make me laugh, Captain.
He seems quite fond of you. You really did make up, didn't you?
We settled our differences, I think. He really is clever and talented, and I hate being at odds with my officers.
That's sensible enough. I-
*ALARM*
It looks like we have some business to attend to.
Time for Lieutenant Luiz and the rest to show what they're really good for!
@BATTLE
Are you all right, Enterprise? You're quieter than I'm used to seeing you after a battle.
I'm fine, Captain. I'll be fine. I promise. The sinking of the Alagoas, and the discovery of the airplane was... well, it hurt. But honestly, I'm fine! We can't cry over spilt milk, can we?
Sometimes your flippancy can be concerning, Enterprise.
We've seen Morgana aircraft carriers use their fighter planes as projectiles twice now.
We should work out our own strategies to counter those attacks. We'll likely fight Delusion again.
I've been discussing the problem with my officers. Do you have any ideas?
I've spoken with Lieutenant Luiz. He thinks it would be helpful to stage aerial battles further away from the ships themselves.
A relatively simple fix. Lieutenant Luiz and his fighters should work on implementing that strategy.
If other Morganas copy Delusion's tactic, the fleet is going to have a problem on its hands. We need to nip it in the bud.
I agree. I'll speak to Command and make sure everyone is on the lookout for signs of her tactic spreading.
Copy that! In the meantime, it looks as if we have trouble headed this direction - there's Morganas off my bow!
Let's go.
@BATTLE
Were you and Lieutenant Luiz just arguing again on the bridge?
No! We were having a spirited debate, but an entirely friendly one this time. I promise.
Good, I'm glad you're getting on. ... Are you blushing, Enterprise? Ha!
Don't laugh at me, Captain!
I just didn't think you were capable of being bashful. What has you flustered?
I'm not! Not usually. It's just... I feel like Lieutenant Luiz... he's very clever, and a very capable lieutenant... but I think he's somehow gotten the idea that he could make me his sweetheart.
Excuse me, what?
I think he's sweet on me.

Fields.MenuText: I can see why. I'm surprised everyone isn't.
What?!
You're a Belle, and his superior. He shouldn't think of such things.

Fields.DialogueText: Augh, don't talk like that, Captain! I'm not that sort of person. He shouldn't be carrying a torch for me.
I think Lieutenant Luiz is carrying a torch for me!
That was my first thought, too. It just seems... I don't know what to do about it.
Both of you really have other things which should be demanding your attention at the moment.
Of course, Captain! Speaking of which, there are Morganas approaching us - just in time!
We can talk more on this later.
Please, no, we really don't have to.
@BATTLE
Hey, look, Captain! More frigate birds! Aren't they gorgeous? Look at how they swoop! They can fly for days on end. Imagine if we could build planes that could do that!
That would certainly be useful.
I'll have to write to Miss Kumar and ask her if such a plane might be possible. I wrote to her - well, that doesn't matter!
What?
Nothing, Captain. It's a lovely day.

Fields.MenuText: Of course. A lovely day.
You're really bad at lying, did you know that?
Don't lie to me.

Fields.DialogueText: A very lovely day. A day that I'm glad to be a Belle, out here at sea, with you.
Lying? Why would I lie to you? You're my captain.
I'm not lying. It is a lovely day!
You're being quite evasive.
You know what else is evasive? A- A- ... There's a Morgana on my RDF!
You're just trying to divert my attention.
No, I swear, Captain! Look, there! It looks like Delusion!
Let me see those binoculars... it does! She looks like she's heading somewhere at full steam. Let's disrupt her plans, shall we?
Of course!
@BATTLE
Run as much as she wants, Delusion won't be able to escape us!

Fields.MenuText: She looks like she's ready for another fight. Are you ready?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Captain!
It's likely she'll try to pull the exploding airplane trick again. Are the pilots prepared?
Of course, Captain! I think our new tactics will work well.
@BATTLE
It looked like that fighter was trying to swerve into us! Hah! Fool me once, but that trick won't work again, Delusion!
Lieutenant Luiz's pilots shot it down quickly. It looks like that was the last trick Delusion had. She's fleeing.
... Captain. That fighter that was trying to crash into us... it looks familiar! Look, it's right off the hull, you can see the markings!
It's one of ours!
Enterprise! Enterprise, come back here!

Fields.MenuText: Think we should call this one in? She might have one more trick up her sleeve.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we better be ready with a seam ripper!

Fields.MenuText: Unless she doesn't want to. She could be luring us.

Fields.DialogueText: That'll be her last mistake!
Captain!
Captain?
I was right, wasn't I? His face was burned, but I could tell - that fighter in the downed aircraft, he was one of ours!
... He was.

Fields.MenuText: That was a brave thing to do, Enterprise.
I'm not sure that justifies you leaping into the ocean...
That was a stupid thing to do, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: It wasn't brave, Captain. I'm a Belle. I know how to swim.
I wasn't in any danger, Cap! I'm a Belle. I can swim like a fish!
It was not! I wasn't putting anyone at risk. I certainly can't drown, not unless my ship sinks as well.
I needed to save that man. I needed to know if he was one of ours, and if he turned willingly or not.
Well, he was one of our pilots, one of those that went missing in the storm, but I'm afraid we'll have to wait for any other answers if we get them at all.
He barely survived that wreck. He was burned and badly injured, and weakened from almost drowning as well... I'm not sure if he'll ever speak.
Did the doctors have any insight, Captain? From his general condition? Was there anything... strange about it?
He looked like he may have been subjected to some form of torture, at some point, but like I said, he's pretty cut up in general.
The doctors were reluctant to come to any conclusions. I'm sorry, Enterprise.
It's all right. I didn't expect a lot of answers... I just needed to save him, just in case any part of him was still in there.
I understand.
... I saw Lieutenant Luiz coming down the stairs on my way up to the deck, looking rather sad. Know anything about that?
... Oh! Oh. I, uh, had to tell him that I... didn't have interest in him. At least, not the way he had interest in me.
I see. Well... I'll see if the doctors have been able to find anything else out from our missing pilot.
... Wait, Captain?
Yes?
... Never mind. It looks like there's Morganas at the edge of my RDF's range. We should give chase.
@BATTLE
Captain, we need to talk.
Oh, Enterprise! I didn't expect to find you in my quarters.
Captain, I think I have feelings for you.
... What?
Feelings. For you. I think I do. I'm sorry I've been bashful and skirting around the issue, because, to be honest... I don't know much about this kind of thing.
I know a lot about friendship, and camaraderie, and blood ties born in battle, but... not a lot about... this. Naval history and sea shanties don't tend to tell you a lot about it.
I can't imagine they do.
So... I needed advice. I sent letters to Miss Kumar, and to my sponsor. They both had... different takes on the situation, but... they gave me some good advice.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you weren't interested in things like love, after how you responded to Lieutenant Luiz's affections.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not that I'm not interested! It's just... I'm not interested in that sort of romance. I'm not interested in being courted, or dancing, or having honeyed words whispered in my ear...
You've always been there for me, Captain. You know just what makes me... me. You encourage me when I need it, and you kick my ass when I need it too.
And I realized, for all my daydreams of flying... I'm happiest when I'm sailing through the seas with you, Captain. You don't have to feel the same. I just wanted to let you know.
I feel the same way, Enterprise.
You do? Really?
I really do.
This is hopelessly poetic, and silly, especially in times like these... but I imagine what I'm feeling right now is a bit like how it feels to fly.

Fields.MenuText: They wouldn't have been the first ones I asked.

Fields.DialogueText: Engineers are people too, Captain! These...these days, ships are as well, you know?

Fields.MenuText: What did they tell you?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, they know how patriotic I am... how I give my all in battle and encourage the crew to do the same. It seems so obvious now, but... I just had to have that same honesty off of the battlefield.
Then don't worry about the silliness.
You... you like it?
You don't worry when you're in a fight, right? You do what has to be done, you give your all, and you don't let up until the job's finished.
Until the job's finished... I'd rather keep this one going, if we're being totally honest.
Where?
Any captain would be lucky to fight at your side. This just proves I'm the luckiest.
... Wherever the hell we want.
